form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Received; read twice and referred to the Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs

form.official-title: To amend title 5, United States Code, to modify probationary periods with respect to positions within the competitive service and the Senior Executive Service, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Ensuring a Qualified Civil Service Act of 2017 or the EQUALS Act of 2017.

section.header: Extension of probationary period for positions within the competitive service

subsection.text: Section 3321 of title 5, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a), by striking The President and inserting Subject to subsections (c) and (d), the President;
by redesignating subsection (c) as subsection (e); and
by inserting after subsection (b) the following:
The length of a probationary period established under paragraph (1) or (2) of subsection (a) shall—

subparagraph.text: with respect to any position that requires formal training, begin on the date of appointment to the position and end on the date that is 2 years after the date on which such formal training is completed;
with respect to any position that requires a license, begin on the date of appointment to the position and end on the date that is 2 years after the date on which such license is granted; and
with respect to any position not covered by subparagraph (A) or (B), be a period of 2 years beginning on the date of the appointment to the position.

paragraph.text: In paragraph (1)—

subparagraph.text: the term formal training means, with respect to any position, a training program required by law, rule, or regulation, or otherwise required by the employing agency, to be completed by the employee before the employee is able to successfully execute the duties of the applicable position; and
the term license means a license, certification, or other grant of permission to engage in a particular activity.

subsection.text: The head of each agency shall, in the administration of this section, take appropriate measures to ensure that—

paragraph.text: any announcement of a vacant position within the agency and any offer of appointment made to any individual with respect to any such position clearly states the terms and conditions of any applicable probationary period, including any formal training period and any license requirement;

any individual who is required to complete a probationary period under this section receives timely notice of any requirements, including performance requirements, that must be met in order to satisfactorily complete such period;

any supervisor or manager of an individual who is required to complete a probationary period under this section receives periodic notifications of the end date of such period not later than 1 year, 6 months, 3 months, and 30 days before such end date; and

if the head decides to retain an individual after the completion of a probationary period under this section, the head submits a certification to that effect, supported by a brief statement of the basis for the certification, in such form and manner as the President may by regulation prescribe.

subsection.text: Section 3321(e) of title 5, United States Code (as so redesignated by subsection (a)(2)), is amended by striking Subsections (a) and (b) and inserting Subsections (a) through (d).
This section and the amendments made by this section—

paragraph.text: shall take effect 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act; and

shall apply in the case of any appointment (as referred to in section 3321(a)(1) of title 5, United States Code) and any initial appointment (as referred to in section 3321(a)(2) of such title) taking effect on or after the date on which this section takes effect.

section.header: Extension of probationary period for positions within the Senior Executive Service

subsection.text: Section 3393(d) of title 5, United States Code, is amended by striking 1-year and inserting 2-year.
Section 3592(a)(1) of such title is amended by striking 1-year and inserting 2-year.
The amendments made by this section—

paragraph.text: shall take effect 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act; and
shall apply in the case of any individual initially appointed as a career appointee under section 3393 of title 5, United States Code, on or after the date on which this section takes effect.

subsection.header: Subchapter I of chapter 75 of title 5
subsection.text: Section 7501(1) of title 5, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking or, except and inserting and, except; and
by striking 1 year of current and inserting 2 years of current.

subsection.header: Subchapter II of chapter 75 of title 5
subsection.text: Section 7511(a)(1) of title 5, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (A)(i) by striking ; or and inserting ; and;
in subparagraph (A)(ii), by striking 1 year the first place it appears and inserting 2 years;
in subparagraph (B) by striking 1 year and inserting 2 years; and
in subparagraph (C)(i), by striking ; or and inserting ; and.

subsection.text: Section 4303(f) of title 5, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: in paragraph (2) by striking 1 year of current and inserting 2 years of current; and
in paragraph (3) by striking 1 year and inserting 2 years.

subsection.text: The amendments made by subsections (a), (b), and (c)—

paragraph.text: shall take effect 1 year after the date of enactment of this Act; and

shall apply in the case of any individual whose period of continuous service (as referred to in the provision of law amended by paragraph (1) or (2) of subsection (b), as the case may be) commences on or after the date on which this section takes effect.

section.text: Not later than 180 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Director of the Office of Personnel Management shall issue such regulations as are necessary to carry out this Act and the amendments made by this Act.

attestation-group.attestation-date: Passed the House of Representatives November 30, 2017.
